alert.note: Alert for King (Washington) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 12 at 4:03PM PST until January 12 at 10:50PM PST by NWS Seattle
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Washington... Snohomish River Near Monroe affecting Snohomish County. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Washington... Snohomish River At Snohomish affecting Snohomish County. Snoqualmie River Near Carnation affecting King County. Snoqualmie River Near Snoqualmie Falls affecting King County. Skykomish River Near Gold Bar affecting Snohomish County. Tolt River Above Carnation affecting King County. .Heavy rain over the Central cascades has come to an end this afternoon. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT FROM THIS AFTERNOON THROUGH THIS EVENING... * WHAT...No flooding is currently forecast. * WHERE...Tolt River Above Carnation. * WHEN...Until late this evening. * IMPACTS...At 3500.0 cfs, the Tolt River will spill over its banks with water over 353rd Ave NE and some driveways in the San Souci area. This river level on the Tolt corresponds to a phase 2 flood in the King County flood system. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:15 PM PST Wednesday the flow was 4700.0 cfs. - Forecast...The river crested at 6200 cfs late this morning and is expected to fell below flood stage around 2 PM this afternoon. Flooding will continue until the flood wave passes downstream. - Flood flow is 5000.0 cfs. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 4680.0 cfs on 10/10/1940. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. Most flood related deaths occur in automobiles. Do not attempt to cross water covered bridges, dips, or low water crossings. Never try to cross a flowing stream, even a small one, on foot. To escape rising water find another route over higher ground. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued by this evening at 1015 PM PST.
